column1: The daily cares
The wretched crewe
And horror of my bloody practise past
Strikes such a terror to my wounded conscience
That sleep I
Methinks their ghosts comes gaping for revenge
Whom I have slain in reaching for a Crown.
Clarence complains
<span class=""quote"">My Nephew's bloods
The headless Peers comes preasing for revenge.
And every one cries
The Sun by day shines hotly for revenge.
The Moon by night eclipseth for revenge.
The stars are turnd to Comets for revenge.
The Planets change their courses for revenge.
The birds sing not
The silly lambs sits bleating for revenge.
The screeking Raven sits croaking for revenge.
Whole heads of beasts comes bellowing for revenge.
And all

column1: Upon my life
Myself to be a marv'lous proper man.
I'll be at charges for a looking glass
And entertain a score or two of tailors
To study fashions to adorn my body.
Since I am crept in favor with myself
I will maintain it with some little cost.
But first I'll turn yon fellow in his grave
And then return lamenting to my love.

column1: Humanae Miseriae discursus.
O whereof boasteth man
Is filthy clay so much ambitious?
Whose thoughts are vain
Whose deeds are damned
Who in his cradle by his childish crying
Presages his mishaps and sorrows denying.
An infant first from nurses tit he sucketh
With nutriment corruption of his nature:
And from the root of endless error plucketh
That taste of sin that waits on every creature
And as his sinews firm his sin increaseth
And but till death his sorrow never ceaseth.
In riper years when youthly courage raineth
A winters blast of fortunes lowring changes
A flattering hope wherein no trust remaineth
A fleeting love his forward joy estranges:
Achieve he wealth
column2: with wasteful wo he bought it

column1: Let substance fail
In staled years when as he seeks the gleaning
Of those his times in studious Arts bestowed
In sum
Soiling the spring from whence his science flowed
In all he gains by perfect judgement gained
A hate of life that hath so long remained.
From height of throne to abject wretchedness
From wondrous skill to servile ignorance:
From court to cart
The joys of life have no continuance:
The king
Their crowns
The Judgement seat hath brawls
The soldiers life is daily thrall to danger
The merchants bag by tempests is abated
His stock still serves for prey to every stranger
The scholar with his knowledge learns repent
Thus each estate in life hath discontent.
And in these trades and choice estates of living
Youth steals on manly state
And age with weakned limbs
With trembling tongue repenteth youthly rage
And ere he full hath learned his life to govern
He dies
column2: and dying doth to dust return.

column1: His greatest good is
Which he in prime of youth hath overpassed.
How for his grains of good he reapt but stubble
How lost by love
Which whilst he counts
And yet his days in self like follies endeth.
Thus mortal life on sodaine vanisheth.
All like a dream
When sun his beam from substance banisheth
Or like the snow at once that dries and sleeteth.
Or as the rainebow which by her condition
Lives by the Sun's reflect and opposition.
Thus life in name is but a death in being
A burden to the soul by earth entangled:
Then put thou off that vail that lets thy seeing
O wretched man with many torments mangled
Since neither child
The storms of wretched life may be asswaged.
And with the Egyptian midst thy delicates
Present the shape of death in every member
To make thee know the name of all estates:
And midst thy pomp thy nying grave remember
Which if thou dost

Since none before he dies is perfect blessed.";"";"";"@005580 A Margarite of America";"setpiece";"VeSp#005109 seven ages of man";"";"Unmarked";"";"";"";"Body of text";"Local reference";"Secondary (Shakespeare Studies)";"@010057

Presageth his mishaps and sorrowes nying.
An infant first from nurces teat he sucketh

And but till death his sorrow neuer ceaseth.

Their crowns

column2: William.  As You Like It.  Act 2
column4: lines 149-173.";"1600";"1600";"1600";"1600";"English";"[Jaques:] <span class=""quote"">And one man in his time plays many parts

column1: his acts being seven ages.At first the infant
Mewling and puking in the nurse’s arms.
Then the whining schoolboy with his satchel
And shining morning face
Unwillingly to school. And then the lover
Sighing like furnace
Made to his mistress’ eyebrow. Then a soldier
Full of strange oaths and bearded like the pard
Jealous in honor
Seeking the bubble reputation
Even in the cannon’s mouth. And then the justice
In fair round belly with good capon lined
With eyes severe and beard of formal cut
Full of wise saws and modern instances;
And so he plays his part. The sixth age shifts
Into the lean and slippered pantaloon
With spectacles on nose and pouch on side
His youthful hose
For his shrunk shank
Turning again toward childish treble
And whistles in his sound. Last scene of all
That ends this strange eventful history
Is second childishness and mere oblivion
Sans teeth

That I must leave you

column1: Who ne'er knew indigence unto their will
Would (out of all their stock of Virtue left
Or out of all new graces they can make)
Make such another piece as Scudmore is
Then might he justly fear; but otherwise
<span class=""quote"">Sooner the Masculine Element of Fire
Shall flame his Pyramids down to the Earth;
Sooner her Mountains shall swell up to Heaven
Or softest April showers quench fires in Hell;
Sooner shall Stars from this Circumference
Drop like false fairy exhalation
Then I be false to vows made unto thee;

column1: <span class=""quote"">A Players passion Ile beleeue hereafter
And in a Tragicke Sceane weepe for olde Priam
When fell reuenging Pirrhus with supposde
And artificiall wounds mangles his breast
And thinke it a more worthy act to me
Then trust a female mourning ore her loue:
Naught that is done of woman shall me please
Natures step-children rather her desease [desire].	";"Marston

column1: Mine eye-balls
At tennis with 'em. Have I liv'd to this?
Malicious Nature! Hadst thou born me blind
Th'hadst yet been something favourable to me.
No breat? No motion? Prithee tell me
Hast shut thine eye to wink at murder
Hast put the sable garment on to mourn
At's death?
Not one poor spark in the whole spacious sky
Of all that endless number would vouchsafe
To shine? You viceroys to the king of Nature!
Whose constellations govern mortal births
Where is that fatal planet rul'd at his
Nativity? That might ha' pleas'd to light
Him out
It be asham'd t' have been the instrument

Of such a good man's cursed destiny.";"";"";"@001625 The Atheists Tragedy";"";"SuMe#001152 horror at a murder you commited yourself / SuId#001153 fortune plays tennis or football / SuId#001154 stars refuse to light the darkness / WoPh#001155 stars reigned at nativity";"Unmarked";"Unmarked";"Tragedy";"";"Dialogue";"Body of text";"Local reference";"Secondary (Annotated edition)";"@010002-14-42.

column6: scene 1.";"1619";"1619";"1619";"1619";"English";"<span class=""annotation"">This scene is very similar to Act 1
column7: scene 2 in Nathan Field's A Woman is a Weather-Cock.";"The play is set in Dijon in Burgundy in the later part of the fifteenth century
column8: in the aftermath of the battles of Grandson
column10: all mentioned in Act I
column13: was a general who had gone into debt to pay the expenses of his troops; unable to repay those charges
column15: and his rapacious creditors refuse to release his body for a proper burial. The general's son has taken his cause to court
column16: but his suit is rejected by the judges
column17: led by the hostile Novall Senior
column18: president of the Dijon parlement. The younger Charalois amazes everyone by offering to assume his father's debts and take his place in prison
column19: thus freeing his father's corpse. A retiring judge named Rochmont is impressed by Charalois' courage
column22: and decides to pay the general's debts himself.

column1: Rochmont has an only daughter named Beaumelle; she is the centre of a set of fashionable and foppish young people
column2: featuring the aristocratic Novall Junior and his hangers-on. Beaumelle's waiting-woman
column4: is a cynical sensualist who tempts her mistress with the idea of marrying to enjoy sexual indulgence with many illicit lovers. Beaumelle's father is so taken with Charalois that he arranges a marriage between the young man and his daughter.

column1: Novall Junior is irate about the marriage
column2: since he has lost his chance of taking Beaumelle's virginity; but Bellapert assures him that the marriage will work to his advantage. Others
column4: perceive the growing intimacy of Novall Junior and Beaumelle
column5: and try to warn the parties involved
column7: Beaumelle consummates her incipient affair with Novall Junior
column8: and Charalois walks in upon them
column9: catching them in the act. Charalois challenges his wife's lover; Novall Junior attempts to avoid the duel
column10: but in the end he fights with Charalois

column1: Charalois stages a mock trial
column2: with his father-in-law Rochmont as the judge. Rochmont
column4: hears Charalois' accusation and Beaumelle's confession
column5: and sentences her to death. Charalois stabs her; Beaumelle dies. Novall Senior discovers his son's death
column6: and has Charalois arrested and prosecuted. Charalois defends himself before the court
column7: and wins an acquittal. One of Novall Junior's followers
column9: is an ex-soldier named Pontalier who was redeemed from debtor's prison by the judge's son; repaying that favour
column10: Pontalier stabs and kills Charalois in the court
column11: and in turn is stabbed and killed by Romont.";"";"@001883 The Fatal Dowry";"";"#002196 A foppish gentleman at his morning toilet";"Unmarked";"Unmarked";"Theatre";"tbe / need to fix biblio and normalised title after transfer";"Dialogue";"Body of text";"Local reference";"Secondary (Annotated edition)";"@010049-245./@010094";"";"";"  Hohl Trillini Regula"

column1: But Lucifer
So now lies lowest in th'Abyss of Hell.
Chain'd till the dreadful Doom
Sits Beelzebub
Who listning downward hears his roaring Lord
And executes his purpose
<span class=""quote"">The morning creeps behind yon Eastern hill
And now the Guard is mine
And foolish Fairies from their Moon-light Play
And lash the Laggers from the sight of day.

column7: scene 1.";"1684";"1684";"1684";"1684";"English";"[Norfolk:] My Queen! my lovely Alban Queen! sure I'me

column1: Already dead
Where Souls like hers receive their blest Rewards.
[Queen Mary:] Turn wretched Duke
column2: or e're Death seals thy Eyes

column1: This moment tear 'em out
Shun me
Or a Goblin damn'd.
[Norfolk:] What says my Goddess Queen?
[Queen Mary:] Is not your wrong'd and mighty Spirit shockt?
And Death a much more welcome Guest than I?
And worse to see me than to feel the Blow?

column1: The father of this black and dismall Issue.
Moor do'st thou know this brat?
[Aron:] Yes
[Chiron:] Accursed Off-spring!
[Demetrius:] It shall not Live.
[Aron:] It shall not; Princes
column2: for the love I bear to you and to the Empress
